text: is invisibility first we need to define
invisibility for start lots of things
are already invisible in some sense a
stealth aircraft or ship is invisible to
radar a sniper hiding under a thermal
shielding blanket is invisible to a
thermal-imaging camera if you could
actually have x-ray vision people's
flesh and blood would be invisible
because x-rays pass straight through
them but you would of course be able to
see everybody bones but we all know that
what we really mean by invisibility is
the type that tops every schoolboys wish
list of superheroes powers being
invisible to the naked eye in broad
daylight and therefore Finn the girls
changing rooms down at the swimming
paths in which case we're dealing with
straightforward optical theory to be
invisible an object must allow light to
pass through it without absorbing
reflecting or refracting it bending it
in anywhere
another things are already invisible we
know they're there but we can't see them
air radio waves
and the Belgian sense of humor things
like glass and water are almost
invisible because they allow light to
pass through them but refracted just
enough to reveal their presence unless
it's the glass door or the Department
stone the human body will actually allow
a certain amount of light through which
is why it's amusing to put a powerful
torch next to your cheek and illuminate
your mags in a scary way but on the
whole humans absorb and reflect light
which is why we can see them as plain as
day but in the Invisible Man HG Wells
came up with a scientific premise for
true invisibility he gave his man the
same refractive index as air so he
didn't absorb or reflect light and he
bent it to exactly the same degree as
the air around him he disappeared for
the same reason that a sheet of glass
disappears in water but his clothes
didn't disappear The Invisible Man had
to undress to become invisible and well
then you came up with a good theory for
invisibility not a method it may be
easier to try an invisibility trick
Victorian showing you how to use an
array of parabolic mirrors to create an
invisibility shield on stage and what
modern version is to use a flat-screen
TV showing the image from a camera
pointing directly backwards behind it so
any body or thing that moves into the
gap between the screen and the camera
disappears meanwhile nanotechnology may
be able to produce a three-dimensional
cloak from carbon nanotubes which would
steer light around any object a bit like
water flowing around a boulder in a
stream failing that we could create a
tunnel portal so that the thing we
wanted a high could be moved into the
past for a bit sadly though both these
ideas are still compatible so the short
answer is yes invisibility is
technically possible but don't expect to
see it anytime soon as my cat's making
that noise
